content:
From Spreadsheets to Scripts: My Journey Automating Accounting with Python My journey into process automation started at an accounting firm, where I quickly found myself buried in repetitive manual tasks and inefficient workflows. From processing invoices to reconciling spreadsheets, I could see how much time was being lost to work that could â€” and should â€” be automated.
When I started working there, I spent the first few months organizing paperwork and doing basic data entry. I quickly realized two things:
Many processes were slow, repetitive, and prone to errors. No one seemed to have time to improve them. Thatâ€™s when I started asking questions: “Does it really need to be done this way?”, “Where are we losing time?”, “How can we simplify this?”
That curiosity led me to redesign small internal workflows. But there were limits. At some point, I realized automation was the only way to scale those improvements â€” and thatâ€™s how my journey into programming began. I chose Python for its simplicity, elegance, and power: with just a few lines, I could achieve more than hours of manual work.
And I never looked back.
Why Automate Accounting Processes? Automation isnâ€™t just about saving time. Itâ€™s a competitive necessity:
âœ… Fewer human errors â€” Scripts donâ€™t get distracted or misplace columns.
âœ… More consistency â€” The process runs the same way every time.
âœ… Scalable efficiency â€” Workload can grow without doubling the team.
âœ… Happier employees â€” Free time for higher-value tasks like analysis and strategy.
âœ… Better compliance â€” Automatically validate rules and generate audit logs.
âœ… Data for decisions â€” Capture real-time metrics and identify bottlenecks.
Automation doesnâ€™t replace people â€” it empowers them.
Why Python? Though itâ€™s often associated with AI and Data Science, Python is a perfect fit for business automation:
ğŸ§  Simple syntax: easy to learn, even for non-developers like accountants.
âš¡ High productivity: do more with less code.
ğŸ”§ Libraries for everything:
pandas, openpyxl: Excel, CSV, structured data smtplib, requests: email, APIs fuzzywuzzy, difflib: smart reconciliations pdfplumber, PyPDF2: PDF extraction playwright, Selenium: browser automation ğŸŒ Connects with everything: ERP, banks, government portals, web services.
ğŸ¤ Massive community: solutions, tutorials, support â€” always just a search away.
Real-World Examples of Python Automation ğŸ’¼ Import and consolidate Excel files â€” hundreds of rows merged in seconds.
ğŸ¦ Smart bank reconciliation â€” match statements using fuzzy logic.
ğŸ“ˆ Automated reporting â€” generate PDFs with charts and send by email.
ğŸ“¥ ERP journal entries via API â€” connect to the ERP to post transactions from CSV files.
ğŸ“Š Internal dashboards â€” lightweight apps with real-time financial data.
ğŸ§¾ Tax validations â€” ensure correct VAT, dates, and NIF before submission.
What About JavaScript/Node.js? JavaScript, with its Node.js runtime, can also be a good option for automating processes â€” especially in companies with strong web development teams. Itâ€™s a versatile language, backed by a large community, capable of handling both simple scripts and complex applications.
However, when it comes to back-office automation â€” reading files, integrating systems, processing structured data â€” Python stands out for its simplicity and power.
JavaScript shines in user interfaces and interactive tools, while Python is the go-to for silent, background automations that handle large volumes of data elegantly.
Both languages can coexist and complement each other. But for those coming from business or accounting roles, and looking to automate daily tasks, Python remains unbeatable thanks to its easy learning curve, library ecosystem, and productivity focus.
The Key Is Internal Knowledge The biggest competitive edge isnâ€™t code â€” itâ€™s knowing the process. When someone from inside the team understands the business and can code, they can build truly useful, tailored solutions.
That was my case: by understanding accounting workflows, I could apply Python to solve real problems. And thatâ€™s what many SMEs need: technology with context.
Weâ€™re here to solve problems â€” thatâ€™s why automation (and even AI) wonâ€™t replace people, but rather empower them. Automating means giving people the right tools to focus on what really matters and make higher-impact decisions.
Conclusion Automating accounting isnâ€™t just about saving time. Itâ€™s about building systems that are efficient, reliable, and human-centered.
If you’re a company, invest in hybrid talent â€” people who understand the business and can code in Python.
If you’re an accounting professional, learn to code. You donâ€™t need to be an engineer â€” just start small. Thatâ€™s how I did it.
Python taught me that automation is about taking better care of the work, the people, and the future of business.
Ready to explore how Python automation can save time, reduce errors, and bring real value to your accounting workflows? Letâ€™s connect! Feel free to reach out via LinkedIn or check out some of my projects on GitHub. Iâ€™m always up for sharing ideas or collaborating on meaningful automation challenges.
ğŸ“Œ GitHub â€¢ LinkedIn â€¢ LeetCode

content:
ğŸ§© Problem: Roman to Integer (LeetCode 13) Convert a string representing a Roman numeral into its integer value. Roman numerals are typically written from largest to smallest (left to right), except for six well-known subtractive cases:
I before V or X â†’ 4, 9 X before L or C â†’ 40, 90 C before D or M â†’ 400, 900 âœ… Clean Idiomatic Solution (One-Pass) class Solution: SYMBOLS = { 'I': 1, 'V': 5, 'X': 10, 'L': 50, 'C': 100, 'D': 500, 'M': 1000 } def romanToInt(self, s: str) -> int: total = 0 prev_value = 0 for c in s: value = self.SYMBOLS[c] total += value - 2 * prev_value if value > prev_value else value prev_value = value return total Single loop Detects subtractive patterns with value > prev_value Clean inline logic âœ… Runtime: 3 ms (faster than 79.17%)
âœ… Memory: 17.6 MB (less than 90.19%)
ğŸ” Overengineered (but fun!) Functional Version def romanToGenerator(s): from operator import add, sub SYMBOLS = { 'I': 1, 'V': 5, 'X': 10, 'L': 50, 'C': 100, 'D': 500, 'M': 1000 } total = 0 prev_val = 0 for c in s: val = SYMBOLS[c] op = sub if prev_val < val else add delta = val if op is add else val - 2 * prev_val total += delta yield total Uses operator.add / operator.sub Yields intermediate results step-by-step Great for teaching or tracing, but slower ğŸ“Š Benchmarks Version Avg. time (100K runs) Notes Idiomatic version â‰ˆ145 ms Fastest and cleanest Overengineered (list) â‰ˆ205 ms Stores operation pairs Overengineered (yield) â‰ˆ195 ms Generator-based, incremental ğŸ§® Complexity Analysis Time Complexity:
Best / Worst / Average: O(n) â€” single pass Space Complexity:
Idiomatic: O(1) (constant variables) Overengineered (list): O(n) (stores ops) Overengineered (yield): O(1) (no intermediate structure) â±ï¸ Time Invested Reading and planning: 20 minutes Coding and analysis: 50 minutes Total: 1h10min ğŸ§  What I Learned Subtractive notation in Roman numerals can be generalized with value > prev_value. The difference between clean idiomatic solutions and overengineered abstractions in Python. How to benchmark Python code using timeit, and what tradeoffs come with generators and operator functions. The value of exploring multiple angles of a problem, even if the first solution works. ğŸŒ Real-World Applications Token-based parsing of custom numeric notations or symbolic expressions. Building interpreters or compilers that evaluate streams of symbols (e.g., financial codes, scientific notation). Teaching clean code versus functional design tradeoffs. Performance benchmarking and complexity analysis in educational content. ğŸ’¬ Personal Note What started as a simple Roman numeral conversion turned into an exploration of Python idioms, operator functions, generator design, and performance benchmarking.
Even the simplest problems can reveal new learning paths if you’re curious enough ğŸ§ 
ğŸ“‚ Code Repository You can find my full source code for this solution on GitHub:
ğŸ“¦ Repo: github.com/fredericogago/leetcode ğŸ“„ File: Roman to Integer.py ğŸ‘¨â€ğŸ’» Like this post? Letâ€™s connect on LinkedIn or check out more on GitHub!
summary:
ğŸ§© Problem: Roman to Integer (LeetCode 13)

Convert a string representing a Roman numeral into its integer value. Roman numerals are typically written from largest to smallest (left to right), except for six well-known subtractive cases:

  • I before V or X â†’ 4, 9
  • X before L or C â†’ 40, 90
  • C before D or M â†’ 400, 900

âœ… Clean Idiomatic Solution (One-Pass)

class Solution:
    SYMBOLS = {
        'I': 1, 'V': 5, 'X': 10,
        'L': 50, 'C': 100,
        'D': 500, 'M': 1000
    }

    def romanToInt(self, s: str) -> int:
        total = 0
        prev_value = 0
        for c in s:
            value = self.SYMBOLS[c]
            total += value - 2 * prev_value if value > prev_value else value
            prev_value = value
        return total
  • Single loop
  • Detects subtractive patterns with value > prev_value
  • Clean inline logic

âœ… Runtime: 3 ms (faster than 79.17%)
âœ… Memory: 17.6 MB (less than 90.19%)
title: Roman to Integer â€” Clean, Fast, and Functional Approaches Compared

content:
ğŸ§© The Problem Given an integer x, determine whether it’s a palindrome â€” that is, whether it reads the same forwards and backwards.
ğŸ”— Problem Link: LeetCode 9. Palindrome Number
Examples Input: x = 121 â†’ Output: True Input: x = -121 â†’ Output: False Input: x = 10 â†’ Output: False Bonus: Can you solve it without converting the integer to a string?
ğŸ” The Three Approaches I Explored 1. ğŸ’¡ Direct Solution with String Conversion def isPalindrome(x: int) -> bool: return str(x) == str(x)[::-1] Simple and fast (4 ms on LeetCode) But does not satisfy the follow-up constraint of avoiding strings 2. ğŸ“ Mathematical Reversal Using log10 and Closed-Form Formula Inspired by this StackExchange post, this solution uses a formula to reverse digits without strings:
reverse(x) = x Ã— 10â¿ âˆ’ 99 Ã— Î£â‚– floor(x / 10áµ) Ã— 10â¿â»áµ âœ… No string conversion âœ… Mathematically elegant âš ï¸ Slightly slower due to log10() and exponentiation âš ï¸ Can suffer from floating-point rounding issues 3. âš™ï¸ Iterative Arithmetic Reversal (Preferred) def reverse(x: int) -> int: result = 0 while x > 0: result = result * 10 + x % 10 x //= 10 return result âœ… No strings âœ… Fast and stable âœ… Easy to understand and debug â±ï¸ Benchmark Results Tested on values like 11, 101, 1001, ..., 10000001
Iterative method: ~0.000009 seconds Math (log10) method: ~0.000033 seconds âœ… Both produce the correct result ğŸ“Œ Iterative is about 3.7Ã— faster and more robust for real-world use
ğŸ§  What I Learned How to reverse integers purely with arithmetic How to benchmark small Python functions using time.perf_counter() That elegance can sometimes come at a performance cost How to choose the right tradeoff between readability, correctness, and efficiency ğŸŒ Real-World Applications Palindrome logic pops up in places like:
Input validation (e.g. palindromic IDs) Data compression using symmetry Embedded systems that donâ€™t allow string types Constraints in coding interviews or systems-level code (like drivers/firmware) ğŸ“‚ Code Repository You can find my full source code for this solution on GitHub:
ğŸ“¦ Repo: github.com/fredericogago/leetcode ğŸ“„ File: Palindrome Number.py âœï¸ Final Thoughts Solving the same problem in multiple ways helps me grow not only as a developer, but as a technical communicator. Being able to solve is great. Being able to explain clearly â€” thatâ€™s where the real value is.
“Hope it helps! Iâ€™m learning to write more elegant solutions with Python 3.13 and Clean Code.” ğŸš€
ğŸ‘¨â€ğŸ’» Like this post? Letâ€™s connect on LinkedIn or check out more on GitHub!
summary:
ğŸ§© The Problem

Given an integer x, determine whether it’s a palindrome â€” that is, whether it reads the same forwards and backwards.

ğŸ”— Problem Link: LeetCode 9. Palindrome Number

Examples

Input:  x = 121   â†’ Output: True
Input:  x = -121  â†’ Output: False
Input:  x = 10    â†’ Output: False

Bonus: Can you solve it without converting the integer to a string?

ğŸ” The Three Approaches I Explored

1. ğŸ’¡ Direct Solution with String Conversion

def isPalindrome(x: int) -> bool:
    return str(x) == str(x)[::-1]
  • Simple and fast (4 ms on LeetCode)
  • But does not satisfy the follow-up constraint of avoiding strings

2. ğŸ“ Mathematical Reversal Using log10 and Closed-Form Formula

Inspired by this StackExchange post, this solution uses a formula to reverse digits without strings:
title: Is It a Palindrome Number? Three Ways to Solve It Without Converting to String

Hi, I’m Frederico Gago, a passionate software developer dedicated to crafting solutions that transform complexity into clarity. I specialize in Python 3.13, Clean Architecture, SOLID principles, and thoughtful design patterns, driven by the belief that great software should feel intuitive, empowering, and elegant.
My mission is to redefine the way professionalsâ€”especially in accounting and financeâ€”interact with their daily tasks. By automating routine processes and eliminating friction, I aim to help people reclaim their focus and creativity, enabling them to achieve more meaningful and impactful outcomes.
This blog is my space to openly share the challenges and triumphs of my technical journey, offering insights and practical examples drawn from real-world experiences. Whether I’m optimizing backend services, designing robust abstractions, or enhancing developer workflows, each post reflects my commitment to continuous growth and excellence.
Feel free to explore my work on GitHub or reach out through LinkedIn. Let’s connect and build software that makes work not just easierâ€”but truly inspiring.
